intro: Macrolobium canaliculatum, commonly known as the channel-ribbed macrolobium, is a flowering plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its distinctive, palmate leaves with deep veins and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. It thrives in humid, tropical environments and is often found in shaded forest understories. Due to its ornamental value, it is cultivated in some botanical gardens and private collections.
